user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of try_match_header:
```c
static int
try_match_header (const char *prefix,
                  size_t prefix_len,
                  char *line,
                  char **suffix)
{
  if (NULL != *suffix)
    return MHD_NO;
  while (0 != *line)
  {
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_ (prefix,
                                   line,
                                   prefix_len))
    {
      *suffix = strdup (&line[prefix_len]);
      return MHD_YES;
    }
    ++line;
  }
  return MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No unreachable code was found in this function. Every statement and branch can be reached depending on runtime inputs: the initial if-return is conditional on *suffix and does not make subsequent code unreachable; the while loop executes only when line[0] != '\0' (so it can be entered or skipped); the inner if may be true (causing an early return) or false (allowing ++line and further iterations); and the final return is reached when the loop completes without a match. There are no constant-false/constant-true conditions, no unconditional returns/gotos that skip later code, and no dead (unreachable) statements. (Note: there are other potential issues such as dereferencing suffix without checking that suffix itself is non-NULL, but that is a runtime/UB/safety concern, not an instance of unreachable code under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1.)
